articles.title: Wages to rise in tight market as economists shrug off migration concerns
articles.text:
Wages to rise in tight market as economists shrug off migration concerns Workers can expect stronger wage growth over the next two years as the federal government looks to drive unemployment to near 50-year lows, with economists predicting even a surge of skilled migrants won't cool the jobs market.

Prime Minister Scott Morrison has set a goal to push the jobless rate towards 3 per cent as the economy recovers from the coronavirus pandemic.

With inflation rising faster than expected and unempl ...

articles.title: How to get a pay rise: bold advice for Aussies
articles.text:
How to get a pay rise: bold advice for Aussies Australians wanting to earn more money will be urged to switch jobs by the federal Treasurer, in a bid to keep the country's labour market growing.

In a speech to the Australian Industry Group on Monday, Josh Frydenberg will encourage Australians to take advantage of a "great reshuffle" to score a pay rise and drive unemployment rates down.

Mr Frydenberg will quote Treasury analysis that shows a record 300,000 workers in the December quarter said  ...

articles.title: Why you should be able to get a job
articles.text:
Why you should be able to get a job The jobless rate fell to a 13-year low of 4.2 per cent in December, down from 4.6 per cent the month prior.

Governor Philip Lowe said earlier this week the rate had "declined to the low fours earlier than we had expected".

The RBA had previously tipped the unemployment rate would fall to 4 per cent by the middle of 2023 but has brought that forward by a whole year to June 2022.

"Full employment" is a jobless rate near 4 per cent or below.

The RBA's central ...

articles.title: Australian businesses' technology failures are hurting incomes
articles.text:
Australian businesses' technology failures are hurting incomes "This suggests that policies to address barriers to business dynamism and competitive pressures can improve Australia's productivity performance, by increasing incentives for firms to adopt, innovate and improve."

The productivity gap between global frontier firms and Australian businesses has grown over time in the non-resource, non-financial market sector, according to Treasury economists Dan Andrews, Jonathan Hambur, David Hansel ...

articles.title: 'Great reshuffle' drives wage growth - but not for all
articles.text:
'Great reshuffle' drives wage growth - but not for all If you want a pay rise, switch jobs. This advice was recently endorsed by Federal Treasurer Josh Frydenberg in a speech to the Australian Industry group. In the same speech he questioned the myth of the "great resignation", suggesting instead we are seeing a "great reshuffle".

The treasury research from 2019 suggests that overall wages grow about 0.5 per cent for every 1 per cent increase in job switches across the labour market as a whole. ...

articles.title: 'Employees' market': Businesses struggle to find staff
articles.text: 'Employees' market': Businesses struggle to find staff With the unemployment rate falling, businesses are struggling to find workers to fill the staff shortage in the wake of the Omicron wave of the pandemic. Carlos Ramirez, owner of Fyshwick restaurant Mr Papa, has been short staffed since December and struggled to find new staff for full, part-time and casual positions. "There is no staff available." "[I have had to] just call friends and ask favors to come and work and help us." The shortage, ...

articles.title: Inflation and tangled supply lines grip the US economy
articles.text:
Inflation and tangled supply lines grip the US economy The struggles of Art Eatables illustrate how inflation and tangled supply chains have seeped throughout the economy, forcing consumers and businesses to make painful decisions. With the US government reporting on Thursday that consumer inflation reached 7.5 per cent over the past year - a 40-year high - the acceleration of prices leaves few unscathed.

Some supply chain snarls that have magnified inflation since the pandemic recession may be ...

articles.title: Australia isn't the US  --  but we're on uncharted ground on unemployment
articles.text:
Australia isn't the US  --  but we're on uncharted ground on unemployment If you told someone a year ago unemployment was about to dive below 5 per cent, to just above 4 per cent, they wouldn't have believed you.

If that person was an expert, and you said it would happen despite a Delta outbreak and lockdowns in our two biggest states, they might have said you had little idea of how the economy worked.

At the beginning of last year, The Conversation asked 21 of Australia's leading economists w ...

articles.title: 'Damn near impossible': This family is giving up meat to make ends meet
articles.text:
'Damn near impossible': This family is giving up meat to make ends meet Amber Johnson prides herself on being a savvy shopper.

The mother of two and her partner are both on a disability pension and, despite their best efforts, they have been feeling the pinch.

Ms Johnson's family is giving up meat, but this is no temporary Lenten sacrifice.

It is the only way to keep their weekly budget under control.

"Usually around Christmas you see things like pork go up and around Australia Day the price ...

articles.title: The unemployment rate is falling quickly. This 'special formula' explains why
articles.text:
The unemployment rate is falling quickly. This 'special formula' explains why In the last 18 years, it's happened on four separate occasions, and it's seen the unemployment rate decline significantly.

And we're living through one of those periods now.

But this period is radically different from the other three.

Let me explain.

Below is a simplified model of the labour force (LF) framework.

It's used by the Bureau of Statistics to produce our labour force statistics.

articles.title: Wages not a trigger for RBA interest rate rises
articles.text:
Wages not a trigger for RBA interest rate rises He still believes wage growth must lift to around 3 per cent for inflation to be sustainably in the 2 to 3 per cent target band.

The cooling housing market, particularly in Sydney and Melbourne, may also buy the RBA a bit more time.

Accommodation and food services was the only one of the 18 industries that experienced annual wage growth above 3 per cent, recording a 10-year high of 3.4 per cent, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

articles.title: High-priced pets, petrol and prams could deliver political pain
articles.text:
High-priced pets, petrol and prams could deliver political pain No amount of political spin can hide the financial reality being felt by Australians every day they rock up to the supermarket, pay an insurance bill or buy that must-have Kate Bush shirt on Etsy.

Prices are going up. And their wages aren't keeping up with those higher prices.

Wednesday's wage price index was another piece of official evidence backing up what people are feeling every day.

Wages have grown by 2.3 per cent over the ...

articles.title: Voters worry about falling wages, back lower migrant intake
articles.text:
Voters worry about falling wages, back lower migrant intake Australians are scaling back their hopes for a swift economic recovery and a boost to wages as the nation heads to an election fight over the cost of living, with 53 per cent of voters expecting their personal incomes to fall in real terms this year.

Only 12 per cent of voters believe their personal incomes will increase above the rate of inflation in the year ahead despite warnings about worker shortages and public forecasts for shrin ...

articles.text:

articles.text:
Wage growth edges higher to 2.3pc Wages grew 0.7 per cent in the December quarter to be 2.3 per cent higher through the year, with hospitality and retail recording the largest rises as businesses competed to attract and retain workers.

Annual growth came in slightly below market expectations of 2.4 per cent and 2.5 per cent, but on par with the quarterly outlook.

"The proportion of pay rises reported over the December quarter was higher than usually seen at this time of year," Australian Burea ...

articles.text:
Finance union knocks back 3pc pay rises at Cbus Cbus has made the controversial decision to pursue its pay offer with staff directly in the face of strong union opposition and claims its proposal will amount to a real wage cut.

articles.text:
'Sydney's full': Barnaby's call to migrants Barnaby Joyce says Australia needs foreign workers now more than ever to plug major labour shortages but has warned aspiring migrants not to aim for Sydney.

The Deputy Prime Minister's call comes after leading economists called for Australia's migrant intake to increase to 190,000 a year.

Treasurer Josh Frydenberg has aimed even higher, saying he anticipates bringing in 235,000 migrants every year within the next few years.

articles.title: Working full-time? How your wages stack up
articles.text: Working full-time? How your wages stack up Tasmanian workers - particularly women - remain the nation's lowest paid on average, but have made up some ground on mainland workers. Average weekly ordinary time earning (AWOTE) for full-time Tasmanian workers increased by $21 between May and November, according to original terms Australian Bureau of Statistics figures. That took the total to $1541.70, below that of every other state and territory and the national average of $1748.40. Male Tasmanian A ...

articles.title: Wages have recorded their worst result in seven years
articles.text:
Wages have recorded their worst result in seven years With a federal election looming, let's get some facts ready.

Wages grew by 2.3 per cent over the 12 months to December, according to the Bureau of Statistics.

That is historically weak.

Between 1998 and 2015, nominal wages always grew by 2.5 per cent or more a year.

However, for the past seven years, they've failed to grow faster than 2.5 per cent.

In fact, they've repeatedly broken records for how slowly they've been growing.

By return ...

articles.title: Retail and hospitality lead pay rises as wage growth starts to accelerate
articles.text:
Retail and hospitality lead pay rises as wage growth starts to accelerate The official measure of wage growth shows base pay rose 2.3 per cent over the year to December.

That was the fastest annual wage growth since the June quarter of 2019, before the COVID-19 pandemic hit in early 2020.

The Bureau of Statistics' wage price index (WPI) rose 0.7 per cent in the December quarter, with public and private sector pay rising by the same amount.

"The proportion of pay rises reported over the Decemb ...

articles.title: If you feel like your spending power is going backwards ...
articles.text: If you feel like your spending power is going backwards ... Not even the nation's strongest wages growth is stopping inflation shrinking Tasmanian workers' spending power. Tasmanian wages increased by 3 per cent in 2021, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics' wage price index, ahead of national growth of 2.3 per cent. However, the state's wages growth significantly trailed the increase in Hobart inflation, which is the best available measure for changes in Tasmanian living costs. The  ...

articles.title: Victoria announces additional kinder year
articles.text:
Victoria announces additional kinder year Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews has announced an Australian-first change to the way kindergarten will operate across the state.

In a major overhaul of Victoria's child education program, three year-old children will be able to access an additional year of the funded program.

Around 2700 services across 79 local government areas will deliver at least five hours per week of program this year, before gradually scaling up to reach the full 15-hour program ...

articles.text:

articles.title: Nearly half of under-25s are studying at uni
articles.text:
Nearly half of under-25s are studying at uni The Productivity Commission Report on Government Services, released today and focusing on childcare, education and training, found that the proportion of young people who left school in 2020 and who, in 2021, were fully engaged in work or study was 74.6 per cent.

This is an improvement on a year earlier when the first onslaught of the pandemic resulted in just 63.2 per cent in work or education.

articles.text:

articles.text:

articles.text:

The scholarship program, now in its second of three years, was launched by the NSW government to boost the number of childcare providers in the state and improve the quality of the care provided. The program has a record number of beneficiaries.

articles.text:

Dr Boston told the forum - run by the NSW Teachers Federation - he regretted that the Howard government's argument that the Gonski school funding model would result in lower independent school fees, allowing parents greater choice, had not eventuated.

articles.text:

articles.title: Kenny High School delayed due to rain
articles.text: Kenny High School delayed due to rain The ACT's new $85 million high school in Gungahlin will not be opened in time for the start of the 2023 school year as wet weather delays have plagued its construction. articles.title: It's been ten years since the Gonski review. These experts say it's all gone wrong
articles.text:
It's been ten years since the Gonski review. These experts say it's all gone wrong  There was plenty of excitement across the political divide when the Gonski review into educational funding was released in February 2012.

Led by businessman David Gonski, and commissioned by the then-Gillard Government, the review was designed to reform school funding and lift outcomes for less privileged students through a new needs-based funding model.

It contained 41 recommendations, including an increase of ...

articles.title: NRL All Star squads named, with Latrell Mitchell among missing big names
articles.text:
NRL All Star squads named, with Latrell Mitchell among missing big names The NRL's Indigenous and Māori All Stars teams have been named and there are some big names missing, including, as previously flagged, Latrell Mitchell.

The men's and women's All Stars games are set to be played next Saturday, February 12, at Western Sydney Stadium, but not all of the stars will be there. Far from it.

Mitchell remains suspended for a high shot that saw him miss South Sydney's run to last year's grand fina ...

articles.title: Addo-Carr the headliner in All Stars teams
articles.text:

As expected, the squads are depleted due to the COVID-disrupted NRL pre-season.

Indigenous pair Cody Walker and Jack Wighton and Maoris Kalyn Ponga and Jarome Luai weren't available.

Neither were Melbourne's Maori big guns Jahrome Hughes and Jesse Bromwich, who both had off-seaso ...

articles.title: Fitzgibbon happy for All Stars selectors to load up on Sharks
articles.text:

articles.text:

Canberra winger Jordan Rapana has accepted a two-match ban for a shoulder charge in Saturday night's All Stars fixture.

articles.title: 'What's he thinking': Cornes slams Stack's cliff-jump stunt
articles.text:

articles.text:

articles.text:

David Kidwell's Maori team will dedicate Saturday night's NRL All Stars performance to the pioneering Olsen Filipaina.

Filipaina, 64, died on Thursday after spending 16 days in ICU battling kidney failure.

Among the first Polynesian players to feature in the NSWRL premiership during the 1980s, Filipaina was lauded by Kidwell for forging a pathway.

articles.text:
'Appalled': Footy coach hit with 20-month ban A member of the Manly-Warringah Sea Eagles coaching staff has been issued a 20-month ban for his role in an alleged brawl that erupted at an Under-16s match at Canberra's Belconnen Oval on Saturday.

Jay Younis, an assistant coach with the Sea Eagles' Harold Matthews Cup side, has until Tuesday to challenge the hefty suspension proposed by the New South Wales Rugby League on Wednesday afternoon.

articles.text:

Kurt Zouma remains available for selection for West Ham's Premier League trip to Leicester on Sunday, manager David Moyes has confirmed.

articles.text:

articles.text:

After three seasons and 45 first-grade games for Canberra, Simonsson has relished his return to Sydney and is gunning to start on the wing in round one.

The 23-year-old could get a chance to impress in Sunday's trial against St George Illawarra at CommBank Stadium.

The opportunity to slot into a "young, really strong" squad and work under Arthur ...

articles.text:
The Fiona Worts 'feelgood' Maccas story highlights the additional pressures facing ALW players On Sunday afternoon, Adelaide United striker Fiona Worts equalled the A-League Women's all-time record for most goals scored by a single player in a match, netting five in the Reds' 8-2 thumping of Brisbane Roar.

Not only was it her club's biggest win in the history of the competition, but Worts also rocketed up to second on the league's Golden Boot ladder. And with just three rounds left, Adelaide co ...

articles.text:

NRL player Zane Musgrove has received a tongue lashing from a magistrate for being untruthful.

articles.text:

articles.title: Brandon Smith and Reece Walsh attempt to use 'Latrell loophole' to end suspensions sooner
articles.text:
Brandon Smith and Reece Walsh attempt to use 'Latrell loophole' to end suspensions sooner Melbourne and the Warriors will attempt to use the same loophole that allowed Latrell Mitchell to serve one week of his six-match suspension in the All Stars game in a bid to free Brandon Smith and Reece Walsh to also make sooner-than-expected NRL comebacks.

articles.title: Mitchell refuses to tone down aggression ahead of return from NRL ban
articles.text:
Mitchell refuses to tone down aggression ahead of return from NRL ban Latrell Mitchell is adamant he does not need to rein in his aggression, with the South Sydney star approved to return a week early from his six-match suspension.

Mitchell has been cleared to return in round two against the Melbourne Storm.

The NRL judiciary decided on Tuesday his absence from the All Stars match earlier this month could count towards his ban.

The rule works in the same way players are able to have State of  ...

articles.text:
Shane Flanagan returns to Dragons in NRL Shane Flanagan returns to Dragons in NRLTroy WhittakerAAPFri, 25 February 2022 8:57AM

Shane Flanagan has returned to St George Illawarra as a list management consultant.

The 2016 premiership-winning Cronulla mentor was an assistant coach to Paul McGregor at the Dragons in 2020 but didn't have a second-year contract option activated when Anthony Griffin took charge.

articles.title: New rule BOOSTS Indigenous NBL prospects
articles.text:
New rule BOOSTS Indigenous NBL prospects A new National Basketball League initiative to boost opportunities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander players, and find the next Patty Mills, is already paying dividends.

The Indigenous Player Rule encourages clubs to recruit eligible Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander players in a bid to increase representation, retain talent and develop genuine pathways to the elite level.

Eligible players are those who have never been fully contracted by an ...

articles.title: Housing shortage hurts regional Australia
articles.text:
Housing shortage hurts regional Australia Housing shortage hurts regional AustraliaStephanie GardinerAAPSun, 30 January 2022 6:02AM

As Dr Raphaella Crosby was preparing to return to her hometown, an intense storm ripped through it, tearing off roofs, up-ending trees and splitting power poles.

The severe weather hit Armidale, a picturesque country town in the NSW northern tablelands, in October, damaging the house she was due to move into from the Gold Coast.

Contending with Mother Nature was  ...

articles.title: Aussie cities where houses cost $1m plus
articles.text:
Aussie cities where houses cost $1m plus Australian residential property prices continue to surge, recording the highest annual rate of growth since June 1989, with three capital cities now tipping the $1m mark for median house values.

CoreLogic data released on Tuesday showed dwelling values had rocketed 22.4 per cent over the past 12 months.

The trend of slowing growth continues, however, with prices up 1.1 per cent last month compared with 1 per cent for December.

CommSec senior economist  ...

articles.title: 'Great contradiction' in housing boom
articles.text:
'Great contradiction' in housing boom Committee for Sydney demands action on soaring home pricesAnton NilssonNCA NewsWireFri, 28 January 2022 12:47PM

Sydney home prices have surged more than 25 per cent in the past year, exposing the housing market's "great contradiction", a new report has revealed.

The Committee for Sydney said in its Aspirations for 2022 report that future generations would be "locked out of their chance at a fair go" if housing policies did not change.

"This is the great c ...

articles.title: Ombudsman launches housing complaint probe
articles.text:
Ombudsman launches housing complaint probe Victoria's Ombudsman will investigate the handling of complaints from public and community housing tenants.

Ombudsman Deborah Glass has received more than 1000 housing complaints in the past year, some about basic services such as power and water.

"All too often we receive complaints about basic needs such as running water and electricity, and reasonably maintained, clean and safe premises," Ms Glass said.

"Many tenants tell us they don't know how to ...

articles.title: 'You feel hopeless': Grieving Queensland family hit by state's worsening housing crisis
articles.text:
'You feel hopeless': Grieving Queensland family hit by state's worsening housing crisis When Yeppoon local Brandi Gilligan's rent increased by $120 a week she decided to try her luck finding another rental home more within the family's budget.

It seemed like a sensible idea at the time. Ms Gilligan had never experienced obstacles to renting before, her partner had a stable income and the pair had a good rental history.

But a statewide housing crisis in regional areas has stopped the family in  ...

articles.title: Snapshot shows who is buying up Tassie properties
articles.text: Snapshot shows who is buying up Tassie properties House prices and a "near impenetrable" private rental market has locked thousands of Tasmanians out of the housing market and exposed the ugly side of the property boom. The Real Estate Industry of Tasmania's latest quarterly report showed median house prices in Tasmania had ballooned to $600,000 and the data shows first-home buyers feeling the crunch. Real Estate Institute of Tasmania state president Michael Walsh said the figures showed more co ...

articles.title: Historic hostel for Aboriginal girls preserved
articles.text:
Historic hostel for Aboriginal girls preserved WA's first employment hostel for Aboriginal girls has been added to the State Heritage list ahead of its transfer to the Noongar community.

Cooinda House -- a California-bungalow style residence in Mt Lawley -- was built in 1933 and 1934 and became a hostel in 1966 for Aboriginal girls looking for jobs in the city.

It was managed by the Methodist Church, but the then-Department of Native Welfare was responsible for the placement of residents.

Eve ...

articles.title: The 'biggest challenge' facing property investors this year
articles.text:
The 'biggest challenge' facing property investors this year Residential property investors should take heart from the predicted bounce-back in the economy over 2022 - but with a few caveats.

While the uplift in the expected economic growth rate from 1.5 per cent in 2020/21 to 3.75 per cent in 2021/22 could prove a major boost, a sooner-than-forecast rise in interest rates and delays in reopening international borders could inhibit returns.

The federal government's Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal  ...

articles.title: Could Australia learn from Singapore to make housing more affordable?
articles.text:
Could Australia learn from Singapore to make housing more affordable? Singapore is an island city-state with about 300,000 more residents than greater Sydney, but far less than 10 per cent of its land area.

Yet, according to economist Cameron Murray, it has managed to boost home ownership for 25-34-year-olds from 60 to nearly 90 per cent over the past four decades, at a time when the percentage of Australians that age who own a home has plunged from 60 to 45 per cent.

So, how have they done it ...

articles.title: Tensions flare as residents accuse Victorian government of 'Big Brother' planning approach
articles.text:
Tensions flare as residents accuse Victorian government of 'Big Brother' planning approach For decades, Kaye Oddie has been involved in community battles to protect the heritage of her patch of North Melbourne and make sure planning decisions reflect what locals want.

But now, she and her Shiel Street neighbours feel like they have been completely cut out of a key planning decision that will soon be made for their street.

"It is just Big Brother, it is nothing short of Big Brother," she said.
 ...

articles.title: Hidden traps of selling in a hot market and buying on the dip
articles.text:
Hidden traps of selling in a hot market and buying on the dip But those who plan to sell now and then wait, say, 12 months to buy on a low, should weigh up the potential risk and rewards before taking the plunge, experts say.

Margaret Lomas, founder of Destiny Financial Solutions, says the decision to sell depends on the location of the property and the investor's overall exit strategy.

"If you are close to retirement or the exit point you had planned for the portfolio is not there yet, I thin ...

articles.title: The 'biggest challenge' facing property investors this year
articles.text:
The 'biggest challenge' facing property investors this year Residential property investors should take heart from the predicted bounce-back in the economy over 2022 - but with a few caveats.

While the uplift in the expected economic growth rate from 1.5 per cent in 2020/21 to 3.75 per cent in 2021/22 could prove a major boost, a sooner-than-forecast rise in interest rates and delays in reopening international borders could inhibit returns.

articles.title: Child among 16 Queensland Covid deaths
articles.text:
Child among 16 Queensland Covid deaths Queensland has reported another 16 coronavirus deaths - including a child under 10 - as the state's daily case numbers rise to 9630.

Chief health officer Dr John Gerrard said the child had a very serious and rare underlying inherited medical condition.

The deaths announced on Wednesday were all over 50, six of whom were unvaccinated, with seven of the 16 deaths coming in aged care.

The toll over the course of the pandemic now stands at 225, with all but  ...

articles.title: Australians paying $41 to see a GP as emergency rooms bear brunt of healthcare pressure
articles.text:
Australians paying $41 to see a GP as emergency rooms bear brunt of healthcare pressure More than a third of all emergency department patients last year could have been treated outside a hospital, but Australians face delays seeing a general practitioner and fork out an average $41 each time despite telehealth measures driving up bulk-billing.

Almost a third of GP patients pay gap fees, and a third in need of an urgent appointment had to wait 24 hours or more in 2020-21, a Productivity Commissi ...

articles.title: Omicron wave would be a public health emergency regardless of new ACT COVID powers
articles.text: Omicron wave would be a public health emergency regardless of new ACT COVID powers Omicron would be considered a public health emergency in the ACT regardless of whether proposed COVID-19 management laws are in place. The ACT government's proposed public health amendment bill would give the government and health authorities the power to make public health directions related to COVID outside of a public health emergency. But Health Minister Rachel Stephen-Smith said the current Omicron wave was a ...

articles.title: Australia's largest warship stranded
articles.text:
Australia's largest warship stranded The Department of Defence has confirmed Australia's largest warship has experienced an "outage" amid reports the vessel is "crippled" in the South Pacific.

Defence confirmed on Monday evening that the HMAS Adelaide experienced a "power outage" that reportedly left the navy's biggest warship "stranded" while on an aid mission delivering supplies to Tonga after this month's devastating volcanic eruption and tsunami.

In a statement, the Australian government i ...

articles.title: Young child among 16 Qld Covid deaths
articles.text:

Queensland has reported another 16 coronavirus deaths - including a child under 10 - as the state's daily case numbers rise to 9630.

Chief health officer Dr John Gerrard said the child had a very serious and rare underlying inherited medical condition, with the rest of the new fatalities being people aged from their 50s to 90s.

articles.title: Qld records 10 deaths, 7588 virus cases
articles.text:
Qld records 10 deaths, 7588 virus cases Qld records 10 deaths, 7588 virus casesNick GibbsAAPTue, 1 February 2022 9:11AM

Another 10 people have died with COVID-19 in Queensland as the state raises concerns about the percentage of aged care residents who have received a booster.

Eight of the ten deaths reported on Tuesday were aged care residents, none of whom had received their third jab.

The state recorded another 7588 COVID-19 cases and released figures about the total number of deaths in ag ...

articles.title: NSW records 30 COVID-19 deaths as 183 people treated in ICU
articles.text:
NSW records 30 COVID-19 deaths as 183 people treated in ICU There were 2,749 people with the virus in hospital in the 24 hours to 8pm yesterday.

Of those people, 183 were in ICU and 70 were requiring ventilation.

A total of 12,818 new cases were confirmed in the reporting period -- 7,913 from positive rapid-antigen tests and 4,905 from PCR swabs.

Of the 30 people who died, one was a man in his 30s who had received two vaccine doses and had no significant underlying health conditions.

Chief H ...

articles.title: Queensland's COVID hospitalisation rate trending down, three new deaths recorded
articles.text:
Queensland's COVID hospitalisation rate trending down, three new deaths recorded Another three Queenslanders have died with COVID-19, taking the total number of deaths in the state since the coronavirus pandemic began to 199.

The state has recorded 7,462 new cases in the latest reporting period.

There are 744 people in hospital being treated for COVID. That includes 46 patients in hospital in intensive care.

Chief Health Officer John Gerrard said of the three people who had died with COVID-19 ...

articles.title: $41 cost behind last year's hospital surge
articles.text:
$41 cost behind last year's hospital surge Aussies are being slugged an average of $41 when visiting the doctor but have struggled to get an appointment in the last year, causing a surge in visits to the emergency department.

Out of 8.8 million emergency department visits nationally, those with health issues that could have been treated by their GP rose to 3.2 million in 2020-21, a Productivity Commission on government owned health services found.

These "GP-like presentations" jumped by 14 per ...

articles.title: With Australia's Omicron death toll mounting, the argument for a COVID royal commission grows
articles.text:
With Australia's Omicron death toll mounting, the argument for a COVID royal commission grows This month, about as many people have died with COVID in Australia -- more than 1,000 -- as die in the whole of a bad year from influenza.

"Because of extraordinarily high virus transmission, we're getting more deaths now in this 'enlightenment' COVID time than in the 'dark ages' time," says Brendan Crabb, research scientist and director of the Burnet Institute.

"On a seven-day average, we are now see ...

articles.title: Victoria records 7810 COVID-19 cases, 41 deaths
articles.text:
Victoria records 7810 COVID-19 cases, 41 deaths Of the new cases reported across the state, 2711 were confirmed by PCR tests, while 5099 were self-reported from rapid antigen tests.

After the first week back at school for Victorian students, more than 2900 pupils and 410 staff tested positive to the virus.

A Department of Education spokesman said no schools have closed because of coronavirus outbreaks or staff shortages.

Health Minister Martin Foley told reporters on Friday that children retu ...

articles.title: 'Mass disability event' taking place right now
articles.text:
'Mass disability event' taking place right now A Pulitzer Prize winner has warned a "mass disability event" is already under way, as numbers of those suffering long-term symptoms after having Covid continue to grow.

And the growing crisis could put more pressure on an already struggling Australian health system, as well as see thousands of people forced to leave their jobs for health reasons.

Ed Yong, a science writer at The Atlantic, has been chronicling symptoms of sufferers post-Covid since ...

articles.title: Most Australians just want things to go back to 'normal'. But how much COVID death are we willing to accept?
articles.text:
Most Australians just want things to go back to 'normal'. But how much COVID death are we willing to accept? Dozens dying of COVID in aged care every day. Residents locked down and isolated in nursing homes as Omicron outbreaks surge. People with disability going without vital services due to a staffing collapse from COVID.

Who could have possibly accepted this would be the result of lifting COVID restrictions and moving out of lockdown?

Us -- we did.

By "us", I mean the social consensus form ...

articles.title: NT records fifth COVID-related death, as hospital numbers rise again
articles.text:
NT records fifth COVID-related death, as hospital numbers rise again The Northern Territory has recorded its fifth death related to COVID-19, a man in his 60s from the remote community of Kintore in Central Australia.

The man died on February 4 and his death was confirmed by NT Health this morning, according to a statement from the NT government released about 5pm on Sunday afternoon.

"The NT government extends its sincere condolences to the man's family and loved ones at this sad time," the s ...

articles.title: Three-quarters of ACT public schools had a case of COVID in first week
articles.text: Three-quarters of ACT public schools had a case of COVID in first week Three-quarters of ACT public schools reported a case of COVID-19 on campus in the first week of term as educators grappled with working through the tail of the Omicron wave. In the first week of term, there were 240 cases of COVID-19 across 68 public schools. There are a total of 90 public schools in the ACT, meaning there were only 22 campuses which did not register a case. An ACT Education Directorate spokeswoman said no sc ...

articles.title: NSW reports 8183 COVID-19 cases, 32 deaths
articles.text:
NSW reports 8183 COVID-19 cases, 32 deaths NSW reports 8183 COVID-19 cases, 32 deathsPhoebe Loomes, Farid Farid and Tiffanie TurnbullAAPSat, 12 February 2022 6:21AM

NSW has reported 8183 new locally acquired cases of COVID-19 and 32 deaths.

Some 1650 people are in hospital with COVID-19, after the number of hospitalisations fell below 2000 this week for the first time since January.

On Saturday the Australian Medical Association NSW joined a campaign from their federal counterpart calling on  ...

articles.title: Aged care COVID boosters to be mandatory
articles.text:
Aged care COVID boosters to be mandatory Australians will need a COVID-19 booster to be considered "up to date" as the federal government moves to mandate third doses for aged care workers.

But it will otherwise be up to states and territories to mandate boosters amid tensions over vaccine requirements for international tourists.

Under new advice from the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation, people aged 16 and older who have received a booster will be considered "up to date" wi ...

articles.title: Qld govt keen to assist aged care centres
articles.text:
Qld govt keen to assist aged care centres Qld govt keen to assist aged care centresLaine ClarkAAPWed, 9 February 2022 10:56AM

Queensland's health Minister says the state government has been asked to assist the private aged care sector amid outrage over how a facility near Brisbane handled a COVID-19 outbreak.

Yvette D'Ath says the Queensland government has stepped in to help the sector and is keen to do more if asked, after reading reports of families volunteering to help loved ones at a short ...

articles.title: Qld govt ready to intervene in aged care
articles.text:
Qld govt ready to intervene in aged care Qld govt ready to intervene in aged careFraser BartonAAPThu, 10 February 2022 11:24AM

The Queensland government has offered to step in amid concern private aged care homes are not coping with ongoing COVID-19 outbreaks.

Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk plans to raise the issue with prime minister Scott Morrison at national cabinet on Thursday, following an announcement defence personal will be available to help.

"These are Queenslanders and they are Austr ...

articles.title: NSW reports 6686 virus cases, 22 deaths
articles.text:
NSW reports 6686 virus cases, 22 deaths NSW reports 6686 virus cases, 22 deathsGina RushtonAAPSun, 13 February 2022 6:10AM

NSW has reported a total of 6,686 new locally acquired cases of COVID-19 and 22 virus-related deaths.

Health authorities say 1614 people are in hospital with the virus, 93 of whom are in intensive care, after the number of hospitalisations fell below 2000 on Wednesday for the first time since January.

On Saturday the Australian Medical Association NSW joined a campaign fr ...

articles.title: Indigenous families battling overcrowding call for quarantine centre closer to home
articles.text:
Indigenous families battling overcrowding call for quarantine centre closer to home Justina Blacksmith and her one-year-old daughter Nyeisha were the first in their household to fall sick with COVID-19 early this month.

Then her uncle and the other five adults living in their small three-bedroom house tested positive.

By day six of their isolation period, all four children had symptoms and their week of quarantine turned into two.

"It was very hard with 11 people in the house," Ms Blacksmith  ...

articles.title: Commonwealth extends biosecurity zones in remote communities as NT records 1,045 COVID cases
articles.text:
Commonwealth extends biosecurity zones in remote communities as NT records 1,045 COVID cases The federal government has extended biosecurity zone measures in a number of remote communities in the Northern Territory for a further two weeks.

The biosecurity zones, which the Commonwealth initially introduced in early February and were scheduled to expire on Thursday, prevent travel to and from remote communities across the Northern Territory.

The Northern Land Council (NLC) said it welcomed the C ...

articles.title: 'We need secure power': Call for moratorium on electricity disconnections in remote COVID-hit communities
articles.text:
'We need secure power': Call for moratorium on electricity disconnections in remote COVID-hit communities Frontline Aboriginal organisations working in remote Northern Territory communities have called for an immediate moratorium on electricity disconnections in households subject to COVID-19 isolation rules.

The organisations have raised concern that families undergoing mandatory isolation in overcrowded homes have experienced frequent power disconnections, cutting off cooling and refrigeratio ...

articles.title: Qld govt defends Wellcamp spend secrecy
articles.text:
Qld govt defends Wellcamp spend secrecy Qld govt defends Wellcamp spend secrecyMarty SilkAAPThu, 17 February 2022 9:49AM

Queensland's health minister has refused to reveal the full cost or outline the tender process for the COVID-19 quarantine facility at Wellcamp amid calls for an audit.

Taxpayers have funded $48.8 million in capital costs for the facility near Toowoomba, which has replaced quarantine hotels.

It's understood the government is spending even more to lease from the Wagner Group ...

articles.title: At-home Covid pill comes with a catch
articles.text:
At-home Covid pill comes with a catch New at-home Covid-19 pill to be available on the PBS from TuesdayCourtney GouldNCA NewsWireTue, 1 March 2022 7:20AM

The first at-home treatment to help in the fight against Covid is set to be made available to vulnerable Australians from Tuesday.

Antiviral pill Lageviro, also known as molnupiravir, has been listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, slashing the cost for those at high risk.

Under the guidelines, doctors will be able to prescribe the dr ...

articles.title: Would you share your home with the government if it meant you could break into the property market?
articles.text:
Would you share your home with the government if it meant you could break into the property market? They say desperate times call for desperate measures, and perhaps that's the situation Australian home ownership finds itself in.

Once a dream, fulfilled by most, it's become a nightmare, unattainable for many.

In 1981, more than 60 per cent of young Australians aged between 25-34 owned a home. The latest census figures from 2016 show that had dropped to just 45 per cent.

The figures are far wo ...

articles.title: Bittersweet buy for hospo honcho touched by tragedy
articles.text:
Bittersweet buy for hospo honcho touched by tragedy  House That! Chief Executive of Australian Hotels Association Bradley Woods buys City Beach mansion Kim MacdonaldThe West AustralianFri, 18 February 2022 2:00AMEmail Kim Macdonald

As a lobbyist for the hospitality industry, Bradley Woods has seen his fair share of parties and good times.

But it took two devastating family tragedies to remind him how - at risk of sounding like an Instagram post - to live his best life.

The death of his two yo ...

articles.title: Mortgage stress to increase in Tasmania as cash rate rises
articles.text: Mortgage stress to increase in Tasmania as cash rate rises At a time when many Tasmanian households are already experiencing mortgage stress, Australia's interest rates are predicted to rise by more than three per cent by 2023, likely leaving more homeowners struggling to meet repayments. Latest data analysis from Digital Financial Analysis (DFA) found that Launceston, including its suburbs of Riverside, Trevallyn, Newstead, Ravenswood and St Leonards, is ranked six in Australia for experiencing ...

articles.title: Investor with 8000 homes calls for negative gearing to be axed
articles.text:
Investor with 8000 homes calls for negative gearing to be axed "I invest to make money. If you're choosing a property because you can then negatively gear it, that's an absolutely crazy investment decision. The government should be looking instead at giving tax breaks to people making good decisions."

Negative gearing is defined by the Australian Tax Office as making an investment that's running at a loss. That is, where the income or profit is less than the expenses, after the interest on the  ...

articles.title: Federal government should run a national shared equity scheme
articles.text:
Federal government should run a national shared equity scheme Within living memory, Australia was a place where people of all ages and incomes had a reasonable chance to own a home. But the Great Australian Dream of home-ownership is rapidly turning into a nightmare for many. Home-ownership rates are falling fast, especially among the young and poor.

Between 1981 and 2016, home-ownership rates among 25 to 34-year-olds fell from more than 60 per cent to 45 per cent. Among the poorest 40 per cent ...

articles.title: 'Like a lottery win': The suburbs where houses earn more than people
articles.text:
'Like a lottery win': The suburbs where houses earn more than people Some Victorian homes earned almost 10 times more than their occupants last year, with houses in one popular coastal suburb surpassing household income by more than $1 million.

Buyers escaping Melbourne lockdowns fled to the coast, spending up big on permanent and holiday homes and sending price hikes above take-home pay in 68 per cent of suburbs, figures from Domain and the Australian Bureau of Statistics show.

The data showe ...

articles.title: Does your house make more money than you?
articles.text:
Does your house make more money than you? Homeowners across NSW are making more wealth from their property than from going to work each day as new figures show rapid house price gains have outstripped incomes in most suburbs.

House price growth exceeded incomes in more than four in five NSW suburbs last year, new modelling from Domain shows, with price rises in half a dozen pockets surpassing household incomes by more than $1 million.

Locations from Bronte and Bellevue Hill in the city's east  ...

articles.title: Why are home prices in this town rising faster than anywhere else in Australia?
articles.text:
Why are home prices in this town rising faster than anywhere else in Australia? When Sally Medcalf was evicted from her home in Kiama on the NSW south coast in January, she never thought her family would be plunged into homelessness.

However, unable to find a new home in the area, she was relieved when a friend offered to let the family camp in her backyard.

"The amount that they want in rent we cannot afford.

"We are a single-income family but my husband makes good money, yet we still can't  ...

articles.title: Affordable housing drive will benefit everyone
articles.text:
Affordable housing drive will benefit everyone The Big Housing Build is in its infancy. It is a critical starting point, but it needs 10 years of concentrated, collaborative effort to get Victoria even up to the national average in terms of social and affordable housing supply.

The developer contribution is not and should not be seen as a tax, nor as a way for governments to avoid their obligations and substitute revenue. The initial media reaction - that the cost will be passed on to home buye ...

articles.title: What Australian women need from the next government
articles.text:
What Australian women need from the next government If politicians are looking to attract the female vote, these are the key economic changes that would deliver the greatest benefit to Australian women, according to economists.

Nearly 7700 women return to violent partners every year due to a lack of affordable housing, modelling commissioned by homelessness advocacy group Everybody's Home has found.

Australia needs an additional 16,800 social housing dwellings for women fleeing domestic violen ...

articles.title: This graph shows why it's so hard to save a house deposit
articles.text:
This graph shows why it's so hard to save a house deposit Australian home values rose almost 10 times faster than wages last year, with the market boom pushing the dream of homeownership further out of reach for more Australians.

House prices across the country surged 22.1 per cent last year, according to CoreLogic figures, while wages rose just 2.3 per cent, the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show.

"That's a massive gap," said CoreLogic research director Tim Lawless. "[However ...

articles.title: Wangaratta council approves multi-storey social housing development for 'security and dignity of a home'
articles.text:
Wangaratta council approves multi-storey social housing development for 'security and dignity of a home' As the debate continues over the Victorian government's proposed social housing levy on developers, Wangaratta council has taken its own bold step forward.

At this week's council meeting, all seven councillors voted to approve the planning permit for a large new social housing development in the rural city.

"The fact that people require social housing is a big issue in our community, and we ...
